Forest Service. USDA.</ref> * [[Ochroma pyramidale|Balsa]] (''Ochroma pyramidale'') * [[Tilia|Basswood]], linden ** [[Tilia americana|American basswood]] (''Tilia americana'')<ref name="rsummit"/> ** [[Tilia heterophylla|White basswood]] (''Tilia heterophylla'')<ref name="rsummit"/> **[[Fagus grandifolia|American beech]] (''Fagus grandifolia'') * [[Birch]] (''Betula'') **American birches *** [[Betula populifolia|Gray birch]] (''Betula populifolia'') *** [[Betula nigra|Black birch]] (''Betula nigra'') *** [[Betula papyrifera|Paper birch]] (''Betula papyrifera'') *** [[Betula lenta|Sweet birch]] (''Betula lenta'') *** [[Betula alleghaniensis|Yellow birch]] (''Betula alleghaniensis'') **European birches *** [[Betula pendula|Silver birch]] (''Betula pendula'') *** [[Betula pubescens|Downy birch]] (''Betula pubescens'') * [[Castanospermum|Blackbean]] (''Castanospermum australe'') * [[Nyssa sylvatica|Black tupelo]] (''Nyssa sylvatica'') * Blackwood ** [[Acacia melanoxylon|Australian blackwood]] (''Acacia melanoxylon'') ** [[Dalbergia melanoxylon|African blackwood]], mpingo (''Dalbergia melanoxylon'') * Bloodwood (''Brosimum rubescens'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wood-database.com/lumber-identification/hardwoods/bloodwood/}}</ref> * [[Acer negundo|Boxelder]] (''Acer negundo'') * [[Buxus sempervirens|Boxwood]], common box (''Buxus sempervirens'') *[[Ocotea porosa|Brazilian walnut]] (''Ocotea porosa'') * [[Caesalpinia echinata|Brazilwood]] (''Caesalpinia echinata'') * Gumbo limbo (Bursera simaruba) * [[Aesculus|Buckeye]] (''Aesculus'') ** [[Aesculus hippocastanum|Horse-chestnut]] (''Aesculus hippocastanum'') ** [[Aesculus glabra|Ohio buckeye]] (''Aesculus glabra'') ** [[Aesculus flava|Yellow buckeye]] (''Aesculus flava'') * [[Juglans cinerea|Butternut]] (''Juglans cinerea'') * [[Umbellularia|California bay laurel]] (''Umbellularia californica'') * [[Cinnamomum camphora|Camphor tree]] (''Cinnamomum camphora'') * [[Calodendrum capense|Cape chestnut]] (''Calodendrum capense'') * [[Catalpa]], catawba (''Catalpa'') * [[Chloroxylon|Ceylon satinwood]] (''Chloroxylon swietenia'') * [[Cherry]] (''[[Prunus]]'') revision.text:
These are '''lists of [[invasive species]]''' by country or region. A '''species''' is regarded as '''[[Invasive species|invasive]]''' if it has been introduced by human action to a location, area, or region where it did not previously occur naturally (i.e., is not a [[native species]]), becomes capable of establishing a breeding population in the new location without further intervention by humans, and becomes a pest in the new location, threatening agriculture and/or the local [[biodiversity]].
The term '''invasive species''' refers to a subset of those species defined as [[introduced species]], for which see [[List of introduced species]].
*[[List of globally invasive species]] **[[List of invasive species in Africa]] ***[[List of invasive species in South Africa]] ****[[List of invasive plant species in South Africa]] **[[List of invasive species in Asia]] ***[[Invasive species in Japan]] **[[List of invasive species in Oceania]] ***[[List of invasive species in Australasia]] ****[[List of invasive species in Australia]] ****[[Invasive species in New Zealand]] ***[[Invasive species in Hawaii]] ****[[List of bird species introduced to the Hawaiian Islands]] ****[[List of invasive plant species in Hawaii]] **[[List of invasive species in Europe]] ***[[Invasive species in the British Isles]] ***[[List of invasive species in Italy]] ***[[List of invasive species in Portugal]] *[[List of invasive species in North America]] **[[Invasive grasses of North America]] **[[Invasive species in the United States]] ***[[List of invasive species in California]] ****[[List of invasive plant species in California]] ***[[List of invasive species in Florida]] ****[[List of invasive species in the Everglades]] ****[[List of invasive marine fish in Florida]] ****[[List of invasive plant species in Florida]] ****[[Burmese pythons in Florida]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Arizona]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in the Indiana Dunes]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Maryland]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Nevada]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in New Jersey]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in New Mexico]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Utah]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in West Virginia]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Wisconsin]] **[[Invasive species in South America|List of invasive species in South America]] ***[[List of invasive species in Colombia]]

Lists general information and resources for invasive species. * [http://tib.islandconservation.org/ Threatened Island Biodiversity database (TIB)]

'''Margham''' is an oil and gas field in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] (UAE) and the largest onshore gas field in the emirate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dusup.ae/margham-field|title=The Margham Gas Plant and Field has functioned as a strategic fuel gas storage facility for Dubai Supply Authority (DUSUP)|last=dusup|website=www.dusup.ae|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> The field is managed by Dusup - the Dubai Supply Authority.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dusup.ae/|title=Dubai Supply Authority (DUSUP) ensures Dubai continues to meet its ever growing energy needs.|last=dusup|website=www.dusup.ae|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> Condensate production ran at some 25,000 barrels per day in 2010. Margham also has an oil production capability.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://gulfnews.com/business/oil-in-dubai-history-timeline-1.578333|title=Oil in Dubai: History & timeline|last=archives|first=Gulf News|date=2010-02-04|work=GulfNews|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref>
Production at Margham commenced in 1984, with three major gas-bearing formations located up to 10,000 feet below sea level. The field is connected by pipeline to Jebel Ali, where the gas condensate is loaded onto tankers for export. Dry gas is now also sent by pipeline to supply the Dubai grid, with consumption increasing since 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.icis.com/resources/news/2018/01/10/10181701/uae-bets-on-alternative-energy-local-gas-production/|title=UAE bets on alternative energy, local gas production|access-date=2018-09-09|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Margham was initially developed as a liquids stripping/gas recycling project (dry gas was pumped back into the reservoir),<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.woodmac.com/reports/upstream-oil-and-gas-margham-field-gas-storage-project-1770930|title=Margham Field Gas Storage Project|access-date=2018-09-09|language=en}}</ref> but now operates as a gas storage facility for Dubai since 2008, allowing Dubai to depend on gas produced from Margham for its elecricity generation and desalination needs. This usage, together with sustainables such as DEWA's [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Solar Park]], means that Dubai has eliminated the use of oil as a domestic energy fuel.
Although it is a major producer with ambitions to develop its trading activities to become a major global LNG hub, the UAE is actually a net importer of LNG.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/business/dubai-supply-authority-agrees-deal-with-japan-s-jera-to-explore-lng-opportunities-1.19125|title=Dubai Supply Authority agrees deal with Japan’s Jera to explore LNG opportunities|work=The National|access-date=2018-09-09|language=en}}</ref>

{{redirect distinguish|Mechanistic Materialism|Mechanistic materialism}} {{refimprove|date = August 2011}} The '''mechanical philosophy''' is a [[natural philosophy]] describing the universe as similar to a large-scale mechanism. Mechanical philosophy is associated with the [[scientific revolution]] of [[Early Modern]] Europe. One of the first expositions of universal mechanism is found in the opening passages of ''[[Leviathan (Hobbes book)|Leviathan]]'' by [[Thomas Hobbes|Hobbes]] published in 1651.
Some [[Intellectual history |intellectual historians]] and [[Critical theory|critical theorists]] argue that early mechanical philosophy was tied to [[disenchantment]] and the rejection of the idea of nature as living or animated by spirits or [[angels]].<ref>{{cite book |last= Merchant |first= Carolyn|date= 1990 |title= The Death of Nature: Women, Ecology, and the Scientific Revolution |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=o_l2uMk2KjsC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |publisher= Harper Collins |chapter= Chapters 4, 9, 10 |isbn= 0062505955}}</ref> Other scholars, however, have noted that early mechanical philosophers nevertheless believed in [[Magic (supernatural)|magic]], [[Christianity]] and [[spiritualism]].<ref>{{Cite book | last = Josephson-Storm | first = Jason | title = The Myth of Disenchantment: Magic, Modernity, and the Birth of the Human Sciences | publisher = University of Chicago Press | date = 2017 | chapter = Chapter 2 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xZ5yDgAAQBAJ | isbn = 0-226-40336-X }}</ref>
== Mechanism and determinism == Some ancient philosophies held that the universe is reducible to completely mechanical principles—that is, the [[motion (physics)|motion]] and collision of [[matter]]. This view was closely linked with [[materialism]] and [[reductionism]], especially that of the [[atomism|atomists]] and to a large extent, [[stoicism|stoic physics]]. Later mechanists believed the achievements of the scientific revolution of the 17th century had shown that all phenomena could eventually be explained in terms of "mechanical laws": natural laws governing the motion and collision of matter that imply a [[determinism]]. If all phenomena can be explained entirely through the motion of matter under physical laws, as the gears of a clock determine that it must strike 2:00 an hour after striking 1:00, all phenomena must be completely determined, past, present or future.
==Development of the mechanical philosophy== {{details|corpuscularianism}} The natural philosophers directly concerned with developing the mechanical philosophy were largely a French group, together with some of their personal connections. They included [[Pierre Gassendi]], [[Marin Mersenne]] and [[René Descartes]]. Also involved were the English thinkers [[Sir Kenelm Digby]], [[Thomas Hobbes]] and [[Walter Charleton]]; and the Dutch natural philosopher [[Isaac Beeckman]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Margaret J. Osler|title=Divine Will and the Mechanical Philosophy: Gassendi and Descartes on Contingency and Necessity in the Created World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gtPISpxGacAC&pg=PA6|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=7 June 2004|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=978-0-521-52492-6|page=6}}</ref>
[[Robert Boyle]] used "mechanical philosophers" to refer both to those with a theory of "corpuscles" or [[atom]]s of matter, such as Gassendi and Descartes, and those who did without such a theory. One common factor was the [[clockwork universe]] view. His meaning would be problematic in the cases of Hobbes and [[Galileo Galilei]]; it would include [[Nicolas Lemery]] and [[Christiaan Huygens]], as well as himself. Newton would be a transitional figure. Contemporary usage of "mechanical philosophy" dates back to 1952 and [[Marie Boas Hall]].<ref>{{cite book|author=S. Fisher|title=Pierre Gassendi's Philosophy And Science: Atomism for Empiricists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4fLSO6y6DhUC&pg=PA205|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=2005|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-11996-3|pages=205 with note 1–6}}</ref>
In France the mechanical philosophy spread mostly through private academies and salons; in England in the [[Royal Society]]. In England it did not have a large initial impact in universities, which were somewhat more receptive in France, the Netherlands and Germany.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Roy Porter|author2=Katharine Park|author3=Lorraine Daston|title=The Cambridge History of Science: Volume 3, Early Modern Science|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2kvjAp92zcYC&pg=PA46|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=3 July 2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-57244-6|page=46}}</ref>
===Hobbes and the mechanical philosophy=== One of the first expositions of universal mechanism is found in the opening passages of ''[[Leviathan (Hobbes book)|Leviathan]]'' (1651) by Hobbes (1651); the book's second chapter invokes the [[principle of inertia]], foundational for the mechanical philosophy.<ref>{{cite book |editor=Patricia Springborg |title=The Cambridge Companion to Hobbes's Leviathan |date= |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-54521-1 |page=92}}</ref> Boyle did not mention him as one of the group; but at the time they were on opposite sides of a controversy. [[Richard Westfall]] deems him a mechanical philosopher.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Sophie. Roux|author2=Daniel Garber|title=The Mechanization of Natural Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=USOoK5tRabAC&pg=PA11|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=2013|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-94-007-4345-8|page=11 note 21}}</ref>
Hobbes's major statement of his natural philosophy is in ''[[De Corpore]]'' (1655).<ref>{{cite book|author=Daniel Garber|title=The Cambridge history of seventeenth-century philosophy: Volume I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BPlkkgIhUXIC&pg=PA581|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=2003|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-53720-9|page=581}}</ref> In part II and III of this work he goes a long way towards identifying fundamental [[physics]] with [[geometry]]; and he freely mixes concepts from the two areas.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Andrew Janiak|author2=Eric Schliesser|title=Interpreting Newton: Critical Essays|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r5IskjtmGJoC&pg=PA34|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=12 January 2012|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-76618-0|page=34 with note 3}}</ref>
===Descartes and the mechanical philosophy=== Descartes was also a mechanist. A [[substance dualist]], he argued that reality was composed of two radically different types of substance: extended [[matter]], on the one hand, and immaterial [[mind]], on the other. Descartes argued that one cannot explain the conscious mind in terms of the spatial dynamics of mechanistic bits of matter cannoning off each other. Nevertheless, his understanding of biology was mechanistic in nature:
:"I should like you to consider that these functions (including passion, memory, and imagination) follow from the mere arrangement of the machine’s organs every bit as naturally as the movements of a clock or other automaton follow from the arrangement of its counter-weights and wheels." (Descartes, Treatise on Man, p.108)
His scientific work was based on the traditional mechanistic understanding that animals and humans are completely mechanistic [[automaton|automata]]. Descartes' dualism was motivated by the seeming impossibility that mechanical dynamics could yield mental experiences.
===Beeckman and the mechanical philosophy=== Isaac Beeckman's theory of mechanical philosophy described in his books ''Centuria'' and ''Journal'' is grounded in two components: matter and motion. To explain matter, Beeckman relied on atomism philosophy which explains that matter is composed of tiny inseparable particles that interact to create the objects seen in life. To explain motion, he supported the idea of inertia, a theory generated by Isaac Newton.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berkel|first=Klaas|date=2013|title=Isaac Beeckman on Matter and Motion : Mechanical Philosophy in the Making|url=https://ebookcentral-proquest-com.libproxy.mst.edu/lib/umr-ebooks/detail.action?docID=3318707.|journal=Johns Hopkins University Press|volume=|pages=76-77|via=ProQuest Ebook Central}}</ref>
===Newton and the mechanical philosophy=== [[Isaac Newton]] ushered in a weaker notion of mechanism that tolerated the [[action at a distance]] of [[gravity]]. Interpretations of Newton's scientific work in light of [[Isaac Newton's occult studies|his occult research]] have suggested that he did not properly view the universe as mechanistic, but instead populated by mysterious forces and spirits and constantly sustained by God and angels.<ref>Josephson-Storm (2017), p. 43</ref> Later generations of philosophers who were influenced by Newton example were nonetheless often mechanists. Among them were [[Julien Offray de La Mettrie]] and [[Denis Diderot]].
==The mechanist thesis== The French mechanist and determinist [[Pierre Simon de Laplace]] formulated some implications of the mechanist thesis, writing:
{{quote|We may regard the present state of the universe as the effect of the past and the cause of the future. An intellect which at any given moment knew all of the forces that animate nature and the mutual positions of the beings that compose it, if this intellect were vast enough to submit the data to analysis, could condense into a single formula the movement of the greatest bodies of the universe and that of the lightest [[atom]]; for such an intellect nothing could be uncertain and the future just like the past would be present before its eyes.|Pierre Simon Laplace|''A Philosophical Essay on Probabilities''}}
==See also== {{Portal|Philosophy}} *[[Causality]] *[[French materialism]] *[[Necessitarianism]] *[[Philosophy of physics]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.angelfire.com/linux/vjtorley/chapter1finala.html An overview of attempts to define "life"] * "[http://www.columbia.edu/cu/augustine/arch/mechanism.htm The Problem of Mechanism]" by David L. Schindler (from ''Beyond Mechanism'') - contrasts the Aristotelian and Cartesian views of nature and how the latter engendered the mechanical philosophy
{{Authority control}}
[[Category:Historiography of science]] [[Category:17th century in science]] [[Category:Natural philosophy]] [[Category:Naturalism (philosophy)]] [[Category:Metaphysical theories]] [[Category:Theory of mind]] [[Category:Determinism]] [[Category:Materialism]] [[Category:Cognitive science]]

In [[chemistry]], '''metal vapor synthesis''' (MVS) is a method for preparing [[metal complex]]es by combining freshly produced metal atoms or small particles with [[ligand]]s. In contrast to the high reactivity of such freshly produced metal atoms, bulk metals typically are unreactive toward neutral ligands. The method has been used to prepare compounds that cannot be prepared by traditional synthetic methods, e.g. Ti(η<sup>6</sup>-toluene)<sub>2</sub>. The technique relies on a reactor that evaporates the metal, allowing the vapor to impinge on a cold reactor wall that is coated with the organic ligand.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.verdampfer-test.de/aspire-cleito/|title=Aspire Cleito Verdampfer Test|last=|first=|date=|access-date=2017-08-20|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The metal evaporates upon being [[resistive heating|heated resistively]] or irradiated with an [[electron beam]]. The apparatus operates under high vacuum.<ref>E. Schmidt, K. J. Klabunde, A. Ponce, A. Smetana, D. Heroux "Metal Vapor Synthesis of Transition Metal Compounds" Encyclopedia of Inorganic Chemistry 2006, John Wiley & Sons. {{DOI|10.1002/0470862106.ia137}}</ref> In a common implementation, the metal vapor and the organic ligand are co-condensed at liquid nitrogen temperatures.<ref>P. L. Timms "Transition metal vapors in chemical synthesis. The direct preparation of dibenzene chromium as an undergraduate experiment" J. Chem. Educ., 1972, volume 49, p 782. {{DOI| 10.1021/ed049p782}}</ref>
In several case where compounds are prepared by MVS, related preparations employ conventional routes. Thus, tris(butadiene)molybdenum was first prepared by co-condensation of butadiene and Mo vapor, but yields are higher for the reduction of [[molybdenum(V) chloride]] in the presence of the diene.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Stephan, G. C.; Naether, C.; Peters, G.; Tuczek, F.|title=Molybdenum 17- and 18-Electron Bis- and Tris(Butadiene) Complexes: Electronic Structures, Spectroscopic Properties, and Oxidative Ligand Substitution Reactions|journal=Inorg. Chem.|year=2013|volume=52|pages=5931-5942|doi=10.1021/ic400145f}}</ref>
==References== <references />
[[Category:Chemical processes]] [[Category:Vacuum]]

page.title: My Journey into the Wilds of Chicago

revision.text:
{{Infobox book <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = My Journey into the Wilds of Chicago: A Celebration of Chicagoland's Startling Natural Wonders | author = [[Mike MacDonald (photographer)|Mike MacDonald]] | language = English | country = United States | genre = Coffee Table Book | publisher = Morning Dew Press | isbn = 978-0-9963119-0-8 | image = File:Front book cover- My Journey into the Wilds of Chicago.jpeg | image_size = 200px | illustrator = Mike MacDonald | pages = 240 pp ''(first edition)'' | awards = | media_type = Print | pub_date = Dec. 21, 2015 }}
'''''My Journey into the Wilds of Chicago''''' is a photo-literary [[coffee table book]] authored by [[Mike MacDonald (photographer)|Mike MacDonald]], with forewords by [[Bill Kurtis]] and [[Stephen Packard]].<ref name=main>{{cite book |last=MacDonald |first=Mike |date=2015 |title=My Journey into the Wilds of Chicago |url=http://chicagonaturenow.com/chicago-nature-book/ |location=Downers Grove, Illinois |publisher=Morning Dew Press |isbn=978-0-9963119-0-8}}</ref> The book is a visual and educational journey through the [[prairie]]s, [[savanna]]s, and other [[remnant natural area|natural area]]s throughout the [[Chicago metropolitan area]].<ref name=SunTimes>{{cite web |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/entertainment/chicago-prairie-wilderness-photography-book-mike-macdonald-interview/ |title=Sunday Sitdown: Photographer journeys to the ‘wilds of Chicago’ |last=Di Nunzio |first=Miriam |date=March 26, 2016 |website=Chicago Sun Times |publisher=Sun Times |access-date=June 22, 2016}}</ref>
The book contains more than 200 photographs and nearly two dozen essays and poems written by MacDonald about [[Chicago]]'s wild side, ranging in geography from the lakefront to prairie lands just north of the border in [[Wisconsin]], to [[Kankakee, Illinois|Kankakee]], [[Lockport, Illinois|Lockport]], [[Batavia, Illinois|Batavia]], and [[McHenry County, Illinois|McHenry County]].<ref name=WTTW>{{cite web |url=http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2016/01/05/photographer-captures-wilds-chicago-new-book |title=Photographer Captures the ‘Wilds of Chicago’ in New Book |last1=Silets |first1=Alexandra |last2=Palmore |first2=Rebecca |date=January 5, 2016 |website=WTTW Website |publisher=WTTW |access-date=June 20, 2016}}</ref>
''My Journey into the Wilds of Chicago'' served as the basis for the website ''ChicagoNatureNow.com!'', a website run by MacDonald.<ref name=ChiNow>{{cite web |url=http://chicagonaturenow.com/ |website=Chicago Nature Now! |title= Homepage |access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> The website is a digital catalog of Chicago's forest preserves, and provides updates of the area's natural events.
==Reception==
The book was positively received, including a review from ''[[Publishers Weekly]],'' which said of ''My Journey into the Wilds of Chicago'', "this impressive, cloth-bound debut is a lucid perspective on the prairie and its native plants and animals; it is celebratory, soulful and poetic, evoking a strong affection for Chicago's unchecked wilderness in a city best known for its iconic lakefront and skyscrapers."<ref name=PW>{{cite web |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-9963119-0-8 |title=Review: My Journey into the Wilds of Chicago: A Celebration of Chicago- land’s Startling Natural Wonders |date=April 4, 2016 |website=Publishers Weekly |publisher=PWxyz, LLC |access-date=June 20, 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.chicagonature.com/Chicago-Book/}} *[http://www.chicagonaturenow.com ''Chicago Nature Now!'' website ]
[[Category:Coffee table books]] [[Category:Books about the United States]] [[Category:American travel books]] [[Category:Nature books]] [[Category:Botany handbooks and guides]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2016}}
{{Fibre sidebar}}
'''Natural fibers''' or '''natural''' '''fibres''' (see [[Spelling differences#-re.2C -er|spelling differences]]) are [[fibre]]s that are produced by plants, animals, and geological processes.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=John|first=Maya Jacob|last2=Thomas|first2=Sabu|date=2008-02-08|title=Biofibres and biocomposites|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0144861707002974|journal=Carbohydrate Polymers|volume=71|issue=3|pages=343–364|doi=10.1016/j.carbpol.2007.05.040}}</ref> They can be used as a component of [[Composite material|composite]] materials, where the orientation of fibers impacts the properties.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/9849324139|title=Natural fibres : advances in science and technology towards industrial applications : from science to market|last=Sousa,|first=Fangueiro, Raul Manuel Esteves de|last2=Sohel,|first2=Rana,|isbn=9789401775137|oclc=938890984}}</ref> Natural fibers can also be [[Felted|matted]] into sheets to make products such as [[paper]], [[felt]] or fabric.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Doelle|first=Klaus|date=2013-08-25|title=New Manufacturing Method for Paper Filler and Fiber Material|url=https://www.osti.gov/scitech/biblio/1091089/|language=English|doi=10.2172/1091089}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gillick|first=T. J.|date=1959-08-01|title=Natural and Synthetic Fiber Felts|url=https://dx.doi.org
10.1021/ie50596a025|journal=Industrial & Engineering Chemistry|volume=51|issue=8|pages=904–907|doi=10.1021/ie50596a025|issn=0019-7866}}</ref>
The earliest evidence of humans using fibers is the discovery of [[wool]] and dyed [[flax]] fibers found in a prehistoric cave in the [[Georgia (country)|Republic of Georgia]] that date back to 36,000 [[Before Present|BP]].<ref>Balter M. (2009). Clothes Make the (Hu) Man. Science,325(5946):1329.{{DOI|10.1126/science.325_1329a}} {{PMID|19745126}}</ref><ref>Kvavadze E, Bar-Yosef O, Belfer-Cohen A, Boaretto E,Jakeli N, Matskevich Z, Meshveliani T. (2009).30,000-Year-Old Wild Flax Fibers. Science, 325(5946):1359. {{DOI|10.1126/science.1175404}} {{PMID|19745144}} [http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/data/325/5946/1359/DC1/1 Supporting Online Material]</ref> Natural fibers can be used for high-tech applications, such as [[Composite material|composite]] parts for automobiles. Compared to composites reinforced with [[glass fiber]]s, composites with natural fibers have advantages such as lower density, better thermal insulation, and reduced skin irritation. Further, unlike glass fibers, natural fibers can be broken down by bacteria once they are no longer in use.
Natural fibers are good sweat absorbents and can be found in a variety of textures. Cotton fibers made from the cotton plant, for example, produce fabrics that are light in weight, soft in texture, and which can be made in various sizes and colors. Clothes made of natural fibers such as cotton are often preferred over clothing made of [[synthetic fiber]]s by people living in hot and humid climates.
==General Information== Natural fibers are made from [[Fiber crop|plant]], [[Animal fiber|animal]], and [[Mineral fiber|mineral]] sources. Natural fibers can be classified according to their origin.
=== Plant fibres === {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible" !Category !Description |- |[[Seed fibre]] |the fibres collected from the seeds of various plants are known as seed fibres |- |[[Leaf fibre]] |fibres collected from the cells of a leaf are known as leaf fibres, ex.-pina, banana, etc.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Fuqua|first=Michael A.|last2=Huo|first2=Shanshan|last3=Ulven|first3=Chad A.|date=2012-07-01|title=Natural Fiber Reinforced Composites|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/15583724.2012.705409|journal=Polymer Reviews|volume=52|issue=3|pages=259–320|doi=10.1080/15583724.2012.705409|issn=1558-3724}}</ref> |- |[[Bast fibre]] |Bast fibers are collected from the outer cell layers of the plant's stem. These fibers are used for durable yarn, fabric, packaging, and paper. Some examples are [[flax]], [[jute]], [[kenaf]], industrial [[hemp]], [[ramie]], [[rattan]], and [[vine]] fibers.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Summerscales|first=John|last2=Dissanayake|first2=Nilmini P. J.|last3=Virk|first3=Amandeep S.|last4=Hall|first4=Wayne|date=2010-10-01|title=A review of bast fibres and their composites. Part 1 – Fibres as reinforcements|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1359835X10001685|journal=Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing|volume=41|issue=10|pages=1329–1335|doi=10.1016/j.compositesa.2010.06.001}}</ref> |- |[[Fruit fibre]] |Fibers collected from the fruit of the plant, e.g. coconut fiber ([[coir]]) |- |[[Stalk fibre]] |Fibers from the stalks of plants, e.g. straws of [[wheat]], [[rice]], barley, [[bamboo]] and [[straw]]<ref name=":02" /> |}
=== Animal fibers === [[Animal fiber]]s generally comprise [[protein]]s such as [[collagen]], [[keratin]] and [[fibroin]]; examples include [[silk]], [[sinew]], [[wool]], [[catgut]], [[angora wool|angora]], [[mohair]] and [[alpaca#Fiber|alpaca]].
* Animal hair (wool or hairs): Fiber or [[wool]] taken from animals or hairy mammals. e.g. sheep's wool, goat hair ([[Cashmere wool|cashmere]], [[mohair]]), [[alpaca wool|alpaca hair]], horse hair, etc. * Silk fiber: Fiber secreted by glands (often located near the mouth) of insects during the preparation of [[Pupa#Cocoon|cocoon]]s. * Avian fiber: Fibers from birds, e.g. [[feather]]s and feather fiber.
=== Chitin === {{Main|Chitin}}[[File:Chitin.svg|thumb|Chemical structure of chitin chains]] Chitin is the second most abundant natural polymer in the world, with collagen being the first. It is a “linear polysaccharide of β-(1-4)-2-acetamido-2-deoxy-D-glucose”.<ref name=":2" /> Chitin is highly crystalline and is usually composed of chains organized in a β sheet. Due to its high crystallinity and chemical structure, it is insoluble in many solvents. It also has a low toxicity in the body and is inert in the intestines. Chitin also has antibacterial properties.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Rinaudo|first=Marguerite|date=2006-07-01|title=Chitin and chitosan: Properties and applications|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0079670006000530|journal=Progress in Polymer Science|volume=31|issue=7|pages=603–632|doi=10.1016/j.progpolymsci.2006.06.001}}</ref>
Chitin forms crystals that make fibrils that become surrounded by proteins. These fibrils can bundle to make larger fibers that contribute to the hierarchical structure of many biological materials.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Meyers|first=Marc André|last2=Chen|first2=Po-Yu|last3=Lin|first3=Albert Yu-Min|last4=Seki|first4=Yasuaki|date=2008-01-01|title=Biological materials: Structure and mechanical properties|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0079642507000254|journal=Progress in Materials Science|volume=53|issue=1|pages=1–206|doi=10.1016/j.pmatsci.2007.05.002}}</ref> These fibrils can form randomly oriented networks that provide the mechanical strength of the organic layer in different biological materials.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Meyers|first=Marc A.|last2=Chen|first2=Po-Yu|last3=Lopez|first3=Maria I.|last4=Seki|first4=Yasuaki|last5=Lin|first5=Albert Y. M.|date=2011-07-01|title=Biological materials: A materials science approach|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1751616110001128|journal=Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials|series=Special Issue on Natural Materials / Papers from the Third International Conference on the Mechanics of Biomaterials and Tissues|volume=4|issue=5|pages=626–657|doi=10.1016/j.jmbbm.2010.08.005}}</ref>
Chitin provides protection and structural support to many living organisms. It makes up the cell walls of fungi and yeast, the shells of mollusks, the [[exoskeleton]]s of insects and [[arthropod]]s. In shells and exoskeletons, the chitin fibers contribute to their hierarchical structure.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Biological Materials Science|last=Meyers|first=M.A.|last2=Chen|first2=P.Y.|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|year=2014|isbn=|location=United Kingdom|pages=}}</ref>
In nature, pure chitin (100% [[acetylation]]) does not exist. It instead exists as a [[copolymer]] with chitin's deacetylated derivative, chitosan. When the acetylized composition of the copolymer is over 50% acetylated it is chitin.<ref name=":1" /> This copolymer of chitin and chitosan is a random or block copolymer.<ref name=":2" />
=== Chitosan === {{Main|Chitosan}}[[File:Chitosan_chemical_structural_formula.svg|thumb|Chemical structure of chitosan chain]] Chitosan is a deacetylated derivative of chitin. When the acetylized composition of the copolymer is below 50% it is chitosan.<ref name=":1" /> Chitosan is a semicrystalline “polymer of β-(1-4)-2-amino-2-deoxy-D-glucose”.<ref name=":2" /> One difference between chitin and chitosan is that chitosan is soluble in acidic aqueous solutions. Chitosan is easier to process that chitin, but it is less stable because it is more hydrophilic and has pH sensitivity. Due to its ease of processing, chitosan is used in biomedical applications.<ref name=":0" />
=== Collagen === {{Main|Collagen}}Collagen is a structural protein, often referred to as “the steel of biological materials”.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/968439866|title=BIOMECHANICS : mechanical properties of living tissues (1).|last=C.|first=FUNG, Y.|date=1981-01-01|publisher=SPRINGER|isbn=1475717520|oclc=968439866}}</ref> There are multiple types of collagen: [[Type I collagen|Type I]] (comprising skin, tendons and ligaments, vasculature and organs, as well as teeth and bone); [[Type II collagen|Type II]] (a component in cartilage); Type III (often found in [[reticular fiber]]s); and others. Collagen has a hierarchical structure, forming triple helices, [[fibril]]s, and fibers.<ref name=":1" />
=== Keratin === {{Main|Keratin}} [[File:Alpha Keratin Basic Structure.svg|thumb|Diagram showing the creation of alpha keratins helical structure.]] Keratin is a structural protein located at the hard surfaces in many vertebrates. Keratin has two forms, [[α-keratin]] and [[β-keratin]] and are used by different classes of animals. The naming convention for proteins follows that for keratin, alpha keratin is helical and beta keratin is sheet like. Alpha keratin is found in mammalian hair, skin, nails, horn and quills, while beta keratin can be found in avian and reptilian species in scales, feathers, and beaks. The two different structures of keratin have dissimilar mechanical properties, as seen in their dissimilar applications. The relative alignment of the keratin fibrils has a significant impact on the mechanical properties. In human hair the filaments of alpha keratin are highly aligned, giving a tensile strength of approximately 200MPa. This tensile strength is an order of magnitude higher than human nails (20MPa), because human hair’s keratin filaments are more aligned.<ref name=":2" />
== Properties == Compared to synthetic fibers, natural fibers tend have decreased stiffness and strength.<ref name=":2" /> {| class="wikitable" |+Tensile Mechanical Properties of Natural Fibers<ref name=":2" /> !Material !Fiber !Elastic Modulus (GPa) !Strength (MPa) |- |Tendon |Collagen |1.50 |150 |- |Bone |Collagen |20.0 |160 |- |Mud Crab Exoskeleton (wet) |Chitin |0.48 |30 |- |Prawn Exoskeleton (wet) |Chitin |0.55 |28 |- |Bovine Hoof |Keratin |0.40 |16 |- |Wool |Keratin |0.50 |200 |} Properties also decrease with the age of the fiber. Younger fibers tend to be stronger and more elastic than older ones.<ref name=":2" /> Many natural fibers exhibit strain rate sensitivity due to their viscoelastic nature.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fratzl|first=Peter|last2=Weinkamer|first2=Richard|date=2007-11-01|title=Nature’s hierarchical materials|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S007964250700045X|journal=Progress in Materials Science|volume=52|issue=8|pages=1263–1334|doi=10.1016/j.pmatsci.2007.06.001}}</ref> Bone contains collagen and exhibits strain rate sensitivity in that the stiffness increases with strain rate, also known as [[Work hardening|strain hardening]]. Spider silk has hard and elastic regions that together contribute to its strain rate sensitivity, these cause the silk to exhibit strain hardening as well.<ref name=":1" /> Properties of natural fibers are also dependent on the moisture content in the fiber.<ref name=":2" />
=== Moisture Dependence === The presence of water plays a crucial role in the mechanical behavior of natural fibers. Hydrated, biopolymers generally have enhanced ductility and toughness. Water plays the role of a [[plasticizer]], a small molecule easing passage of polymer chains and in doing so increasing ductility and toughness. When using natural fibers in applications outside of their native use, the original level of hydration must be taken into account. For example when hydrated, the Young’s Modulus of collagen decreases from 3.26 to 0.6 GPa and becomes both more ductile and tougher. Additionally the density of collagen decreases from 1.34 to 1.18 g/cm^3.<ref name=":2" />
==Applications== [[File:19th century knowledge weaving flax hemp jute manila sisal vegetable fibers.jpg|thumb|19th century knowledge weaving [[flax]], [[hemp]], [[jute]], [[Manila hemp]], [[sisal]] and vegetable fibers]]
=== Industrial Use === Of industrial value are four animal fibers, wool, silk, camel hair, and angora as well as four plant fibers, cotton, flax, hemp, and jute. Dominant in terms of scale of production and use is cotton for textiles.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Fibers, 1. Survey|encyclopedia=ULLMANN'S ENCYCLOPEDIA OF INDUSTRIAL CHEMISTRY|authors=Erik Frank, Volker Bauch, Fritz Schultze-Gebhardt and Karl-Heinz Herlinger|year=2011|doi=10.1002/14356007.a10_451.pub2|publisher=[[Wiley-VCH]]}}</ref>
=== Natural fiber composites === {{Main|Biocomposite}} Natural fibers are also used in composite materials, much like synthetic or glass fibers. These composites, called biocomposites, are a natural fiber in a matrix of synthetic polymers.<ref name=":6" /> One of the first biofiber-reinforced plastics in use was a cellulose fiber in phenolics in 1908.<ref name=":6" /> Usage includes applications where energy absorption is important, such as insulation, noise absorbing panels, or collapsable areas in automobiles.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Heng|first=Jerry Y. Y.|last2=Pearse|first2=Duncan F.|last3=Thielmann|first3=Frank|last4=Lampke|first4=Thomas|last5=Bismarck|first5=Alexander|date=2007-01-01|title=Methods to determine surface energies of natural fibres: a review|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/156855407782106492|journal=Composite Interfaces|volume=14|issue=7-9|pages=581–604|doi=10.1163/156855407782106492|issn=0927-6440}}</ref>
Natural fibers can have different advantages over synthetic reinforcing fibers. Most notably they are biodegradable and renewable. Additionally, they often have low densities and lower processing costs than synthetic materials.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Rajesh|first=Murugan|last2=Pitchaimani|first2=Jeyaraj|title=Mechanical Properties of Natural Fiber Braided Yarn Woven Composite: Comparison with Conventional Yarn Woven Composite|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1672652916603852|journal=Journal of Bionic Engineering|language=en|volume=14|issue=1|pages=141–150|doi=10.1016/s1672-6529(16)60385-2}}</ref> Design issues with natural fiber-reinforced composites include poor strength (natural fibers are not as strong as glass fibers) and difficulty with actually bonding the fibers and the matrix. Hydrophobic polymer matrices offer insufficient adhesion for hydrophilic fibers.<ref name=":7" />
=== Nanocomposites === {{Main|Nanocomposite}}Nanocomposites are desirable for their mechanical properties. When fillers in a composite are at the [[Nanometre|nanometer]] length scale, the surface to volume ratio of the filler material is high, which influences the bulk properties of the composite more compared to traditional composites. The properties of these nanosized elements is markedly different than that of its bulk constituent.
In regards to natural fibers, some of the best example of nanocomposites appear in biology. [[Bone]], [[Abalone|abalone shell]], [[nacre]], and tooth [[Tooth enamel|enamel]] are all nanocomposites. As of 2010, most synthetic polymer nanocomposites exhibit inferior toughness and mechanical properties compared to biological nanocomposites.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/10.1146/annurev-matsci-070909-104424|title=Mechanical Principles of Biological Nanocomposites|last=Ji|first=Baohua|last2=Gao|first2=Huajian|date=2010-07-02|website=https://dx.doi.org/10.1146/annurev-matsci-070909-104424|language=en|doi=10.1146/annurev-matsci-070909-104424|access-date=2017-05-08|bibcode=2010AnRMS..40...77J}}</ref> Completely synthetic nanocomposites do exist, however nanosized biopolymers are also being tested in synthetic matrices. Several types of protein based, nanosized fibers are being used in nanocomposites. These include collagen, cellulose, chitin and tunican.<ref name=":22" /> These structural proteins must be processed before use in composites.
To use cellulose as an example, [[semicrystalline]] microfibrils are sheared in the amorphous region, resulting in microcrystalline cellulose (MCC). These small, crystalline cellulose fibrils are at this points reclassified as a whisker and can be 2 to 20 nm in diameter with shapes ranging from spherical to cylindrical. Whiskers of collagen, chitin, and cellulose have all be used to make biological nanocomposites. The matrix of these composites are commonly hydrophobic synthetic polymers such as polyethylene, and polyvinyl chloride and copolymers of [[polystyrene]] and polyacrylate.<ref name=":22" /><ref name=":12" />
Traditionally in composite science a strong interface between the matrix and filler is required to achieve favorable mechanical properties. If this is not the case, the phases tend to separate along the weak interface and makes for very poor mechanical properties. In a MCC composite however this is not the case, if the interaction between the filler and matrix is stronger than the filler-filler interaction the mechanical strength of the composite is noticeably decreased.<ref name=":22">{{cite journal|last2=Alloin|first2=Fannie|last3=Dufresne|first3=Alain|date=March 2005|title=Review of Recent Research into Cellulosic Whiskers, Their Properties and Their Application in Nanocomposite Field|journal=Biomacromolecules|volume=6|issue=2|pages=612–626|doi=10.1021/bm0493685|last1=Azizi Samir|first1=My Ahmed Said}}</ref>
Difficulties in natural fiber nanocomposites arise from dispersity and the tendency small fibers to aggregate in the matrix. Because of the high surface area to volume ratio the fibers have a tendency to aggregate, more so than in micro-scale composites. Additionally secondary processing of collagen sources to obtain sufficient purity collagen micro fibrils adds a degree of cost and challenge to creating a load bearing cellulose or other filler based nanocomposite.<ref name=":22" />
=== Biomaterial/Biocompatibility === {{Main|Biomaterial}}Natural fibers often show promise as biomaterials in medical applications. Chitin is notable in particular and has been incorporated into a variety of uses. Chitin based materials have also been used to remove industrial pollutants from water, processed into fibers and films, and used as [[biosensor]]s in the food industry.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Mohanty|first=A|last2=Misra|first2=M|last3=Henrichsen|first3=G|date=March 2000|title=Biofibres, biodegradable polymers and biocomposites:An overview|url=|journal=Macromolecular Materials and Engineering|volume=276|pages=1–24}}</ref> Chitin has also been used several of medical applications. It has been incorporated as a bone filling material for tissue regeneration, a drug carrier and [[excipient]], and as an antitumor agent.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Biomaterials: The Intersection of Biology and Materials Science|last=Temenoff|first=J.|last2=Mikos|first2=A|publisher=Pearson/Prentice Hall|year=2008|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Insertion of foreign materials into the body often triggers an immune response, which can have a variety of positive or negative outcomes depending on the bodies response to the material. Implanting something made from naturally synthesized proteins, such as a keratin based implant, has the potential to be recognized as natural tissue by the body. This can lead either to integration in rare cases where the structure of the implant promotes regrowth of tissue with the implant forming a superstructure or degradation of the implant in which the backbones of the proteins are recognized for cleavage by the body.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
